examples.german: Erleben Sie in Dresscode‑Fragen Unsicherheit bei Ihren Kunden? Ja – aber wenn Business Attire erwartet wird, ist damit Geschäftskleidung gemeint, also Anzug , Krawatte und ein Hemd in Weiß oder einer Pastellfarbe zwischen Blau und Flieder. Und wer das nicht trägt, sticht als schlecht informiert oder nachlässig hervor.
examples.english: Do you experience uncertainty among your customers when it comes to dress code issues? Yes - but if business attire is expected, this means business attire, i.e. a suit, tie and a shirt in white or a pastel color between blue and lilac. And anyone who doesn't wear this stands out as ill-informed or careless.

examples.german: Den Trachtenjanker lässt Hubert Aiwanger im Schrank, wenn er zweimal im Monat nach Berlin fliegt. Für die Bundeshauptstadt muss es schon ein Anzug sein, dunkel, Nadelstreifen, edle Krawatte. Der Bundesvorsitzende der Freien Wähler will nicht unangenehm auffallen in Berlin – zumindest nicht äußerlich.
examples.english: Hubert Aiwanger leaves his traditional jacket in the closet when he flies to Berlin twice a month. For the federal capital it has to be a suit, dark, pinstripes, and a classy tie. The Federal Chairman of the Free Voters does not want to attract unpleasant attention in Berlin – at least not externally.

examples.german: Gegen Lyme‑Borreliose gibt es keine Impfung, aber Antibiotika. Ist man in der Natur unterwegs, sollte man lange Hosen und Oberteile mit langen Ärmeln tragen, sodass die Haut möglichst bedeckt ist. Außerdem sollte man offene Stellen an der Kleidung vermeiden. Also Hemd in die Hose und Hosenbeine in die Socken stecken.
examples.english: There is no vaccination against Lyme disease, but there are antibiotics. If you are out in nature, you should wear long pants and tops with long sleeves so that your skin is covered as much as possible. You should also avoid open spots on your clothing. So tuck your shirt into your pants and your trouser legs into your socks.

etymology: Interviews.'Questioning of well-known personalities by journalists', especially for the mass media press, radio, television. Around 1870, the English interview “meeting, discussion” was adopted into German. The expression is an anglicized formation of mfrz.frz.entrevue 'gathering', a derivation from the verb entrevoir 'to see oneself fleetingly, to meet', afrz.entreveoir (see lat.inter, s.1inter-, and lat.vidēre 'to see'). The common meaning of 'interview' today has evolved with the journalistic workforce...

etymology: Jeans Plur. 'Cotton trousers with quilted seams', as blue jeans adopted from the American-English in the 20th century, cf. English blue 'blue' and English jean 'twilled cotton fabric' may be traced back to French Gênesaufital. Genova, German Genoa, the name of the once important northern Italian transshipment port for cotton. Today mostly jeans, even for those colored other than blue.

etymology: Cameraf.'photographic and film recording device'. In the 19th century, shortened English camera stands for the 'photographic apparatus', which was adopted into German and in the 20th century it was transferred to the 'film apparatus' (film camera). –Cameraman m.'who with the film app...
